text:
All right. So today, I'm going to talk
about some of the new work we're doing on improving
computational efficient power

descent guidance via
transformer-based type constraint prediction. But before I get
into that, I really want to give an
overview of the work

that I do in my group and
some of the AI-related work that we're doing in space.

So this is my group
at MIT ARCLab, so with the Astronautics Space
Robotics and Controls Lab.

And we focus on
these four areas. Today, you'll hear
a lot about the work we're doing in AI for space.

But I do want to mention
some of the other work we're doing in my group. We do a lot of work in space
sustainability and understanding

space debris and
how that's going to be an ever increasing problem
for the space population.

You saw that. Obviously, everyone in the
world saw the solar storm that happened a few weeks ago.

So we do a lot of
work in space weather. So that was a really big storm. But even the minor storms
has effect on satellites.

And so we do a
lot of work there. Analytical astrodynamics, so
like Marco mentioned earlier,

space dynamics. So we do a lot of work
in space dynamics, understanding trajectories
of satellites,

and how to improve modeling
of those trajectories. But what I want to
talk to you about today

is a lot of the work we're doing
in entry, descent, and landing and in particular, the
guidance problem there.

So optimal control approaches
to power descent guidance are not computationally
efficient

enough for the types of things
that we want to do in space. And so the issue is that we have
resource constrained processors,

and we might need to solve
these optimal control problems over long horizons. So how are things
currently done in space?

So this is not--
this sort of equation here is not too far from where
the state of practice is.

So this equation is very
similar to something that folks in the room
that have done space have heard of, which is called
the Apollo guidance solution.

So during Apollo, we had these
polynomial guidance solutions. Now, these guidance
solutions are very simplified

optimal control problems. Typically, you consider it a
flat planet, flat planetary body, so gravity pointing
along the z direction.

And energy-based cost function. Under those assumptions
and with no constraints,

you can derive a
polynomial-based guidance solution. And then you can do things
like fitting the coefficients

of that polynomial-based
guidance solution to actually deliver a
practical implementation.

So that's something that
NASA and JPL and ESA are using for some of
their entry descent guidance applications.

Of course, one of the most
impactful work done in this area is SpaceX and the reusable
launch capability with Falcon 9.

And they've done short
horizon optimal maneuvers. So a lot of that work is using
successive convexification

and lossless convexification
of the entry descent landing problem. But they're really
looking at short horizon

near the powered
descent initiation and calculating
optimal maneuvers.

So it's a step forward. But in reality, we're looking to
deliver humans and exploration

missions to other planets. And we have really high mass
requirements for going to Mars

and returning to the
moon because there might be humans on boards. And the high mass
requirements really

pushes the envelope in
terms of what we can do. So we're going to need optimal
fuel, optimal solutions. And we might need to
execute large diverts.

So we might be landing in more
interesting locations, where we don't have good maps. So the accuracy of the maps of
the areas that we're landing

might require large diverts. So now, what I'm
going to do is I'm going to do a quick overview
of a lot of the work that we're doing in
this area before getting

to the main topic of the talk. So what have we
done in this area? What are some interesting
things that we've looked at?

So in the past we've done a lot
of deep reinforcement learning approaches to try to alleviate
this problem of real time,

closed loop guidance solutions
for the entry, descent, and landing problem. So one of the issues that
we have in entry, descent,

and landing is, how do we
move from simplified 3 degree of freedom solutions, so you
think about this as a point mass

particle, to 6 degree
of freedom solutions that have complicated
actuator geometry

and take into account the
rotation of the craft? So that's very difficult to do. And that's one problem where a
reinforcement learning or neural

network based
solution, we've been able to show in the literature,
can help us solve that problem. So for example, here we have
a fairly large divert area.

And what I'm showing
here is sampling of the train trajectory. And over this large
divert area, we

can use a reinforcement
learning solution to learn, not necessarily
optimal trajectory,

this is using a
technique called G pops to optimize the trajectory
with our neural network

solution. So we can learn how to
do closed loop guidance. We pay a penalty in
terms of optimality.

Optimality here is paid in
terms of either our time

to landing or fuel mass use. So you pay a penalty
in optimality, but you do get a closed
form or a closed loop

6 degree of freedom solution. Other things we've looked at
with reinforcement learning is, what about
when we have things

that we can't model very
accurately on board, or we have changing
environments? So one problem that's
really interesting

is landing a craft on an
asteroid or a small body. So in this case, the rotational
state of the small body

might be something you measure. The actual map of the landing
location might be uncertain. And so you're taking
in these measurements.

And what you have to
do is in closed loop, decide what trajectory
the craft is going to follow to land
safely on the body.

And this is a really
nice application for Meta reinforcement learning. And the reason
for that is we can

deal with things, such
as unknown dynamics for the asteroid, if the
gravitational field is not

fully resolved, landing under a
non-Markov observation process,

we don't have the full
state information, or dealing with
cases like engine failure, large mass variations.

And the folks that are
not familiar with Meta-RL, it's a really nice
approach because it

allows you to adapt online
to any of these situations. So if one of your engine fails,
you can adapt and handle that.

Other things that
we've been doing in terms of learning-based
approaches for this problem

is, those polynomial solutions
that NASA and ESA use,

they like them because
they're very simple. And you can do things,
like analytically calculate

provable stability bounds. But obviously, they're
not fuel optimal. And they're the
relatively simple.

What if we can do things
like adaptive guidance, where we treat the coefficients
as adaptive terms that

are learned through simulation
and can adapt online? So here, what we're showing
you is an adaptive guidance

solution, where-- sorry, it's hard to
see here on the screen. But the red curve here is
the classical solution.

The black curve is
the optimal solution. And the blue curve is
the adaptive solution. You see, the classical
solution can't

deal with this keep-out
zone constraint, where we have a landing
zone that is in this valley.

And so the glide slope
here can be pretty steep. And so the classical
solution, if you're coming in with
too much velocity,

can't handle this
constraint here. Whereas the numerical solution
can obviously really easily

handle that constraint, but
it's computationally expensive. With some of these reinforcement
learning solutions, we can have the same structure
as the classical solution,

have the same
provable guarantees, but be able to handle more
complicated scenarios. And then finally, many
of you that have done

work in this area, you know
that terrain relative navigation is a big problem.

That's something that we're
really interested for landing on the moon, landing on Mars. We might not have
GPS on these planets.

We definitely don't have it now. But in the future, the
moon might have GPS. And in this case,
what we want to do is,

can we take this
terrain information, use it to derive a
optimal control policy?

And so the way we do
this is in simulation, we train a reinforcement
learning agent

to analyze this
terrain information and determine, where is
a safe landing location

and decide on where
it should land. So the way this will work
is you have sub policies.

And you might have
a hovering policy that hovers over a
given location, looking

for a safe location to land. And then once that safe location
to land has been identified, the policy might
switch and then you

enter into the terminal
descent policy and land on a given location.

And so things like this are
really the types of problems that we're trying to
solve in this area.

Just to give you guys
a motivation and a feel for the breadth of problems
and power descent guidance, I'm going to talk about the
main topic of this talk, which

is the power descent
guidance that we've been doing using transformers
to predict tight constraints.

So we have a paper that we've
presented at the Sci Tech conference.

If anyone's interested in
the code for this work, here's our GitHub link. And I just want to acknowledge
the main student that's

been really great at
pushing this work forward, fantastic Julia Briden. And this is the work that
she's been working on.

All right, so what's
the motivation for this? Well, for rover
applications, we might

have a simplified
approach for helping us deal with constraints. So consider this rover
going from this location

to the green dot, and we have
this complicated constraint geometry. These are keep out zone.

These might be craters. And we might know
where these keep out zones are ahead of time,
but we want to online plan

a path from the starting
location to this goal. So one technique to do that are
these search-based planners.

So the search-based planners can
find a solution for this problem

under relatively low
fidelity dynamics and without potentially
actuator constraints.

Then we take that
solution and we might pass that solution into a
model predictive control scheme. And then the model
predictive control scheme--

this is a movie. Sorry, I must have
clicked through it. All right, well,
anyways, it's the movie.

The model predictive control
scheme takes this solution here and further refines that for
more complex actuator dynamics

and control schemes. So this structure of having some
initial guess, some information

about the structure
of the problem, then passing that to a model
predictive control scheme, this

is something that's commonly
done and is appealing. And then so our
motivating goal is, can we do something like that
for entry descent landing

guidance? And let's talk about that
problem in particular. And so the solution
we're proposing is we've done a lot of
work here on model free RL.

And then model free
RL, you can do things, like closed loop guidance. It's fast. And then on the other
side of the spectrum,

you have sequential
quadratic programming, which is the alternative
approach, which is formulate the optimal control
problem, either convexify

or convert that optimal
control problem into a sequence of quadratic problems
that you then solve,

which can be
computationally expensive and might not be real time
for space applications.

And then somewhere in
between is the approach that we're shooting for. We're not necessarily
model free. So we don't want to
necessarily be model free,

but we want to speed up
this quadratic programming problem for the entry,
descent, landing problem.

All right, so let's
talk about how we can improve the computational
efficiency of the power descent problem.

All right, so to
accomplish precise landing, the goal you want
to think about is we want to have
computational trajectories

on the order of milliseconds. So for other applications,
doesn't sound too bad. But you have to
remember, in space,

we have very
constrained hardware. So our space hardware,
hardware that are on these rovers,
hardware that

are on these entry
descent landing vehicles are constrained.

And so the trajectory
generation problem for space, as many of you have seen in
this robotics seminar in class,

is we can define that by
defining a cost function and defining a set
of constraints. So there's equations of motion
that become our constraints.

And there's additional control
constraints that we have. And then that problem
looks something like this.

So for example, we might
have a terminal cost term, a running cost term,
our equations of motion,

some inequality constraints
that we have to deal with, and then some
boundary conditions. And this is really a general
formulation of the problem.

In a second, I'll show you
what it looks like specifically for the space problem. So the equations of motion,
those are equality constraints.

Inequality
constraints might be-- oops, sorry. Inequality constraints
might be dynamic constraints

on the vehicle, glide slope
constraints, fuel constraints. And the boundary
conditions might be, if you have a
fixed final time,

or if you start at
an initial position.

OK, so then the
typical scheme here is then to map this non-convex
formulation into a second order

cone program through a process
of lossless convexification. And so this is a very common
technique in power descent

landing in the last few years. This technique is
similar to the technique that SpaceX uses for Falcon 9.

It was developed by
Behcet and, I'm sorry,

I'm drawing a blank on the
second author's name, Blackmore at SpaceX in the
early 2015 time frame.

And essentially,
this can convert this into a second order
cone program that we can

solve using a convex solver. But the issue here
is that we have

to assume a fixed final time. The other issue here is after
we go through the discretization

of this problem-- yeah, so I'll just mention
before I go to the next step. So just looking back
at this problem,

so what's specific about this
power descent landing problem

that we have is the
dynamic equations is given by these two
equations, but we're also adding

a mass dynamics equation. So the thrusting, turning on
the entry descent landing, is going to change the
mass of the craft which

changes our dynamics. Then we have these
complicated constraints. So some of these constraints
have to do with the thrust

to weight ratio of the
craft, maximum lower bounds, the control vector constraints. We can't point the thrust
in any given direction.

Tilt constraints, so the
craft can't tilt horizontally. Glide slope constraint, we
can't come in at too much

of an aggressive angle. Dry mass, so there's
actual structural mass that we have on the vehicle.

And fuel rate constraints,
there's only so much fuel rate that we can put
through the engine,

so we have that as a constraint. And then finally, here, we
have our equality constraints, initial conditions,
final conditions.

The thing to point out about
all of these constraints is these constraints
here are always active.

We always have to
follow the dynamics. These constraints
down here are always active as well, the initial
condition constraints

and the active constraints. These constraints
here are complex and make the problem
harder to solve,

but are not necessarily
always active.

OK, so we can convert this
continuous time problem into a discrete time problem
by discretizing our trajectory

and considering n nodes. So this is your classical
direct optimization method.

And we can solve this with
an interior point method or an alternative solver. But essentially, we convert
these continuous equations here

to sets of discrete constraints. So we might have
n control points. So if we have n control points,
the total number of constraints

are 15n plus 9. The 15n are these constraints
here that are a function of n,

number of control points. So we're discretizing
the trajectory. At each point of the trajectory,
our dynamics must be valid.

And then these equality
or inequality constraints must be valid at each
point of the trajectory.

And then at these two
points of the trajectory, our boundary conditions
constraints must be valid.

So 15n plus 9. And then if we look
at this problem, this is the crux of the
problem and our ability

to solve this in real time. So if we look at
this 15n plus 9, these are the total
number of constraints.

As we start increasing
the size of the problem from a smallish problem, you
can think about those smaller problems as solving a
rover on a lunar surface

under simplified dynamics
all the way to the problem that I showed you in the last
slide with complex dynamics. As you start increasing the size
of the problem, which you might

need more control points for,
the number of constraints grows linearly, but
it can get quite large for running on board.

But if you look
at the difference between the constraints that
we're always going to have,

which is this green line here
and then the constraints that might be active or
inactive, there's actually quite a big difference
in the size of problem

that you're solving. So if ahead of time, if you
had an indication on which constraints are active, you can
reduce the size of the problem

significantly and
maybe alleviate some of the runtime
issues that we're having for onboard computation.

So here's the idea of the
tight constraint prediction. So we want to be able
to predict two things.

I said last on
the previous chart that for entry, descent,
landing, power descent,

the final time in
those equations, if we fix the final
time, we can convert that

into a coning problem
with fixed final time. But if we want to solve
problems with free final time,

then we can give an estimate of
the final time to that problem and still use the setup there.

The other thing we
can do is we can try to estimate which
constraints are tight. So what we want to do
is we want to learn

a mapping between parameters. So these parameters are
relevant dynamical parameters of the vehicle and a strategy.

The strategy might be, which
tight constraints do I go for? What optimal final time
should I shoot for?

And we can leave
that final time fixed or iterate on that final time
to increase the fuel optimality.

And so essentially,
what we do is we input states that look like
this initial velocity position

glide, so pointing
angle, engine angle. And then we output
a representation

that looks like this. And so this is outputted
essentially as a one hot vector and identifying which
one of these constraints

are active for that particular
problem and a fixed final time. Then we go back with
this information

and we solve this problem here. And we've basically looked at
which one of these constraints

are active and remove the
ones that are inactive. And now, we're
solving that problem.

All right, so the
goal here is to learn a mapping between the
problem parameters and the optimal strategy.

And so optimal, you might not
use transformers as the approach that we chose, but you could use
optimal classification trees.

You could use feedforward
neural networks. But we've tried
those things, they've been shown to be less accurate. And then unlike
transformer and LSTMs,

what we've seen in
our work is that transformer-based
neural networks process the entire
sequence in parallel

and can attend over the
entire input sequence and derive what the
relationships are

between the elements to
give us which constraints are more likely to be active. And so this is what
the setup looks like.

So we have an input vector here. These are our
parameters that are

the input to the transformer. They are state representation
of the problem given before.

And the idea is
that the transformer is going to output which
constraints are active and the final time.

And now, with the quadratic
programming problem I showed on the last slide,
we can use this initial guess,

this initial constraint
activation to solve the problem in a lot faster--

in a lot shorter amount of time. So this is the process
for training the problem

setup that we have. So we choose-- this is
during training data. We choose a bunch of
initial state vectors,

and we solve this problem
repeatedly during training. We give that to our second
order coning problem solver,

and then that problem
outputs which constraints are active for the optimal
solution, which constraints are active and the
optimal final time.

Then we build a data set
for certain initial states, which constraints are active
and what the final time is.

And then we train this
transformer in PyTorch, in this case, and then
we test the network.

And then in real
time applications, this is what it looks like
on board of a spacecraft. So you might have your
initial state, which

is determined from sensors. That initial state goes into
the neural network transformer architecture, and it
outputs which constraints

are going to be tight for
that particular problem and an estimate
of the final time. Then that goes to
a fixed final time

solver, that for a fixed final
time, that optimal estimate and the active
constraints determines

whether things are feasible and
also outputs the trajectory. If things are not
feasible during that case,

then you feed that back in, and
then you adjust the final time by making it longer, making
the final time longer until you

find a feasible trajectory. So this is what some of
the solutions look like.

So in this case, we
did 50 discrete nodes. And we generated, for training
data, 242,000 samples.

80% were training,
20% were testing. And we benchmarked
the transformer

for this application. And it was-- sorry,
the benchmark without

the transformer for this
application was about one-- sorry, 1,600 milliseconds
plus or minus 300.

So that's without
the transformer. So that can't run on board. For that particular problem I
showed you, fixed final time,

that's not going to be
able to run on board. So with the
transformer-based method, we were able to reduce the
computational time by 80--

by 78% just by predicting
which constraints are active and getting a better
estimate of the final time.

And now, the runtime, the mean
runtime was 373 milliseconds

with a standard deviation
of 600 milliseconds. Now, you can consider that
maybe a little bit borderline,

but that's within the realm of
things that we can run on board. And in this case, 100% of the
trajectories were feasible.

Now, if you don't find
any feasible trajectories, then you iterate your
quadratic program solver

until you get a
feasible trajectory. But in this case that
we-- in our test data, we had 100% of the
trajectories were feasible.

But that's not to say
that in some cases, you might generate a
non-feasible trajectories.

So I do want to talk a
little bit briefly about how to interpret this, how
to understand this.

And so one way to
understand this is that what the
transformer is trying to do through
learning the embedding

is learning these sections
of the state space that might behave differently.

So you can think about these
sections of the state space as being these linear planes in
a high dimensional space that

behave differently when it comes
to solving the optimal solution. And these different sections
might have different constraints

that are active. So you might be able to group
these into different clusters to have different
constraints that are active.

It might have
different final times. So the idea is the transformer
is learning some sort of pattern like this. Can we look at a similar
technique like a t-SNE

to try to identify, what are the
patterns that the transformer is learning? So what we did here is we used
t-SNE with the transformer.

So we took initial input
data for the transformer. When does it predict
that constraints

are active for the data? When does it predict that the
less constraints are active?

So in this case, you have
the number of constraints that are active here. And we saw that there
was this clear grouping

of two structures in the
transformer's learned behavior. There's this cluster here, where
a lot of active constraints

were active. And there's this
cluster here, where not many of the
constraints were active.

And so we have more
tight constraints for this cluster, less tight
constraints with that cluster.

So there were two clear
clusters in analyzing the data. But when we looked at
interpreting this data

and looked at the performance,
we also saw another pattern. This cluster here, cluster
two, which on the last slide

is where less
constraints were active, had a much tighter
final position bound.

So these were easier problems. And somehow, the transformer
was able to identify these easier problems.

And you can see that
their landing position accuracy was much tighter. The landing velocity, the z
velocity, was much tighter here.

And the initial z position
and glide slope angle

These are the problems where
there are a lot of constraints

that are active. And in these cases, it
might take longer for you to find a solution because
there's more constraints that

are active. But these are the
problems that have wide-- might have wide diverts. So the initial position
deviation can be fairly large.

The glide slope angle
deviation can be fairly large. So really, you see
this pattern here that there's two classes
of initial conditions.

The hard problems, if a
lot of tight constraints and the problems that have
very few tight constraints.

And if we look at the variation,
the standard variation

of the position for
these two problems, you can see that
these hard problems, much larger standard
deviation, higher velocities,

and higher initial positions. All right, so in conclusion,
by leveraging the attention

mechanism of the transformer,
the transformer-based powered descent guidance enables
millisecond level prediction

of the optimal strategy,
which reduces the runtime of 3 degrees of freedom landing.

I showed you 6 degree
of freedom when I did survey of all of
the work that we've done. That's really where we
want to go with this work.

3 degree of freedom is great
and you can implement that. And one way to really
solve this for on board is, you basically
separate the problems.

The attitude problem
and the position problem become two separate problems. You solve the 3 degree of
freedom problem this way,

and then you close the loop
for an attitude controller. That might not necessarily
be optimal for large diverts

when the vehicle has to go
through large tilts and attitude maneuvers. So we want to get
to the point where

we can do 6 degree of freedom
on this scale of seconds for generating trajectory.

Now, looking at visualizing
the result of the transformer, so like trying to understand
what the transformer was

learning, we saw
that t-SNE suggested that the
transformer-based guidance

efficiently characterize
the samples based on which ones were tight
constraints and the final time

predictions. And we saw that there
was two groupings. One grouping had a lot
of tight constraints. One grouping didn't have
so many tight constraints.

And the transformer was
really separating the problem into these two groupings. One lobe of the t-SNE
plot corresponding

to the tight constraint range
around the sample trajectory, indicating that you can get
more efficient solutions

and the transformer was more
confident for this input range. And the transformer-based
approach

is generalizable to any
optimization problem. So what we're
showing you here, you can try it in other
problems, but we just

tried it on this one. So the results here are
for the entry, descent, and landing problem.

And so we're looking
at other approaches.

This utilize the mean
square error training. And then the
accuracy predictions

are prioritized over
constraint satisfaction. But we're looking at other
approaches for future work

on other cost functions. We do have a paper, if
anyone's interested on looking at other cost functions
for this problem here.

And I'll just put it
in the question slide. So if you're interested
in this problem, but maybe investigating
other cost functions,

we have a constrained in form
learning full paper on that. The GitHub for
our implementation

of the transformer-based
type constraint predictions, if you want to try
it on your problem. Trajectory optimization,
you can find that there

and our full papers here. Do one acknowledge

that also supported this work.

And with that, hopefully, we
have some time for questions. [APPLAUSE]
Thank you.

And we have ample
time for questions. All right.

Hi, can you hear me? Yeah. Thank you for the presentation. So obviously, the

was drastically

with loss of optimality there?

That's a good question. Let me see if I can
get back to this slide.

Actually, I think it's on. Yeah, so the base
problem didn't change.

So when the transformer-- what
the transformer was doing was determining which one of these--

think about the transformer
going through and crossing out these equations, just putting
a line through it and saying,

you don't need that one,
you don't need that one, you don't need this one. But the base problem
didn't change. But internally to
the base problem,

that knowledge of which
constraints are active can significantly reduce
the optimization space

that you need for
solving the problem. So the base problem
didn't change, it's still this base problem.

So at most, we're running
the same speed as this. So at most, we're
running the same speed

of what I quoted you earlier. Hopefully, we're doing better. But the worst we can do is
what this problem solved.

So there is no
loss of optimality? There shouldn't be. The only thing that you
were concerned about is feasible solutions.

If you could generate a loss
of runs slower, if you output--

if somehow, your constraint
tightness is wrong

and the optimizer can't find
a feasible solution for what you told it, but then
you can iterate and solve

the original problem,
again, in that case. So that's why we had that loop. If it fails, go back and
solve the original problem.

Cool, thank you. And I just had a
quick follow-up. Where does this extend for
when you have stochastic state

estimation? It seems like there's no
reasoning here about-- maybe

with ground-based navigation,
there's a lot of uncertainty, is that baked into this problem?

Not yet. But the way that that's-- I mean, it could be applied in
spaces, like an MPC structure,

but not yet. So one way we could do
this is run this online in MPC structure.

And there is
uncertainty in space. So like, for example,
when you look at some of the neural network
solutions we were doing

you're going through
an atmosphere, the uncertainty of where you're
going to turn on your engines can be quite large.
